image.caption: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress

profileText: A Representative from Colorado; born on a small farm near Kansas City, Kans., on July 9, 1875; moved with his mother to Pueblo, Colo., in 1880; moved to Denver in 1889; attended the public schools; engaged in newspaper work as copyholder, reporter, city editor, and managing editor; city auditor of Denver 1899-1901; member of the first convention elected to draft a charter for the city of Denver in 1903; editor of the Rocky Mountain News 1906-1911; president of the International League of Press Clubs in 1906 and 1907; president of the Colorado State Board of Land Commissioners 1911-1913; purchased the Pueblo Leader and moved to Pueblo in 1912; elected as a Democrat to the Sixty-third, Sixty-fourth, and Sixty-fifth Congresses (March 4, 1913-March 3, 1919); chairman, Committee on Expenditures in the Post Office Department (Sixty-fifth Congress); unsuccessful for reelection in 1918 to the Sixty-sixth Congress; editor and manager of Labor, official weekly newspaper of the associated railroad labor organizations, published in Washington, D.C., until his retirement in 1953; died in Washington, D.C. on March 18, 1965; interment in Cedar Hill Cemetery, Suitland, Md.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Keating, Edward. The Gentleman from Colorado: A Memoir. Denver: Sage Books, 1964.

researchRecord.name: In the papers of Harry B. Dynes, 1873-1945, 1 box and 1 folder.
In the papers of Raymond E. Willis, 1936-1950, 4 boxes.
1900-1964, 25 feet.
researchRecord.description: Collection includes correspondence, diaries, book manuscripts, speeches, photographs, portraits, memorabilia, and other material relating to his political and newspaper careers. Finding aid in repository.

researchRecord.name: 1912-1918, 1 cubic foot.
researchRecord.description: Collection includes photographs and memorabilia. Finding aid in repository.

researchRecord.name: In the correspondence of the American Association for Labor Legislation, 1915-1920, 5 linear feet on 9 microfilm reels.
In the papers of Max Meyer, ca. 1920-1953, 4 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: Collection includes correspondence with Edward Keating regarding insurance and exemption for bank employees from Social Security law.

researchRecord.name: In the records of the American Association for Labor Legislation, 1905-1943, 56 linear feet on 71 microfilm reels.
In the papers of Marvin Sanford, 1896-1970, 213 items.
researchRecord.description: Collection includes manuscript written by Edward Keating.

researchRecord.name: In the papers of Elias Tobenkin, 1899-1963, 11.5 linear feet.
In the papers of James A. Frear, 1883-1940, 1.2 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: Collection includes letters of note from Edward Keating.
